headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then there's been a good amount of conversation on M&A in general. I was just wondering if you could take a step back at a higher level and how you see the market right now as far as of the bid-ask spread? There's been some consolidation, there's been
componenttext: And then there's been a good amount of conversation on M&A in general. I was just wondering if you could take a step back at a higher level and how you see the market right now as far as of the bid-ask spread? There's been some consolidation, there's been some transactions recently in the space. How do you see ONEOK bidding into that? Any thoughts would be helpful.

headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so Jeremy, we continue to assess opportunities and the challenges continues to be to find opportunities or potential targets that are willing to transact. The bid-ask spread is still wide. I think there will be more transactions. And certainly for u
componenttext: Well, so Jeremy, we continue to assess opportunities and the challenges continues to be to find opportunities or potential targets that are willing to transact. The bid-ask spread is still wide. I think there will be more transactions. And certainly for us, as we think about transactions and we not just -- not just from an M&A perspective but acquisitions, do they strategically make a lot of sense, and is there good fit? Do they make sense within our footprint? Do they bring an inordinate amount of commodity risk to us? Or do they perhaps bring a lot of fee-based, stable fee-based business to us? Those are all the things that we think about. And certainly, our bias is to -- more toward fee-based and not as much commodity exposures as some of the midstream businesses have.

headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Well, sure, John. We would, I don't think we draw bright lines here and we're certainly looking forward to even beyond '17, as we think about going back to increasing the distribution. So if we've got good line of sight, I don't know that we're going to draw a bright line. But as I mentioned, we continue to see that leverage ratchet down and you've really seen that quarter-after-quarter here. I don't expect that to change.

headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just following on Jeremy's question on the M&A front. I mean, if there are -- I mean, are you looking at, say, any kind of step-out opportunities or something where you think you'd like to geographically be in areas where you aren't currently? headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of the transactions or potential targets that we think about are -- do have some overlap within our existing footprint, but do modestly reach into some other areas. I think that could make sense for us. Looking something -- looking at a collection of
componenttext: Most of the transactions or potential targets that we think about are -- do have some overlap within our existing footprint, but do modestly reach into some other areas. I think that could make sense for us. Looking something -- looking at a collection of assets, standalone, significantly outside our geographic footprint, just buying stuff because it's -- perhaps you can get it at a good value, certainly doesn't have much appeal to us. But yes, modestly outside our footprint could make some sense.

componenttextpreview: What's the remaining flared gas capture opportunity in North Dakota look like? How much of a backlog do you think you have there?
componenttext: What's the remaining flared gas capture opportunity in North Dakota look like? How much of a backlog do you think you have there?

headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kevin. Yes, we're still in that $70 million, $70 million to $80 million a day range. We have brought on Bear Creek. We don't have the state reports, the flaring, a couple of months in arrears. So we don't have that data yet to give the exact numbe
componenttext: This is Kevin. Yes, we're still in that $70 million, $70 million to $80 million a day range. We have brought on Bear Creek. We don't have the state reports, the flaring, a couple of months in arrears. So we don't have that data yet to give the exact numbers. But I would absolutely -- I mean, we know the flaring has gone down as Bear Creek has ramped up. We've just, as recently as last weekend, kind of completed the last step of a gathering system expansion that put out some additional flares. So I would expect that run rate -- we're expecting that run rate maybe to be in the 5% range kind of going forward if we think about our total production and the gas capture we expect going forward.

componenttext: Oh, okay. Yes, 5% of the production. So if you go back to that theoretical chart that we had put out there, we're in that -- a little over $800 million a day of production on our acreage. So if you look at 5% of that, $40 million, $50 million a day of flared gas maybe ongoing.

headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when on -- as you look forward, when would you see that opportunity exhausted in terms of, at -- some point are you going to be capturing every new molecule that's produced? Are we going to see a consistent backlog there as producers continue to bring
componenttext: And when on -- as you look forward, when would you see that opportunity exhausted in terms of, at -- some point are you going to be capturing every new molecule that's produced? Are we going to see a consistent backlog there as producers continue to bring on wells and flared gas?

headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think of that it's ever going to go away completely. I mean, there's always going to be some level of flared gas just due to ongoing -- you're always tying in new infrastructure and new well connects. You're always going to have operational
componenttext: Well, I don't think of that it's ever going to go away completely. I mean, there's always going to be some level of flared gas just due to ongoing -- you're always tying in new infrastructure and new well connects. You're always going to have operational hiccups. So there's always going to be some level of flaring. And that's what I think that 5% range, that would be kind of an ongoing run rate.

componenttext: Craig, this is Sheridan. Yes, we're still confident. We are still -- we are out there actively engaged with a lot of potential new processing plants that are coming on. componenttext: Yes, this is Phill. I think it would be a -- probably a good multiple project. It's, at this point, just expansion. But yes, it's probably 200 million to 400 million a day, I would say, is the sweet spot for us. And it provides a lot of interconnectivity with the interstate pipelines out in West Texas. So seems to be very popular discussion because of the value associated with getting the molecules out there.

headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And look, there's some noise in the quarter. Some things a little better than one would have expected. Gas pipes had a good quarter, you had some down, some of the more volatile margin stuff with spreads. But you basically met Street expectations. And you
componenttext: And look, there's some noise in the quarter. Some things a little better than one would have expected. Gas pipes had a good quarter, you had some down, some of the more volatile margin stuff with spreads. But you basically met Street expectations. And you're guiding to flattish to up fourth quarter NGL volumes and rising G&P volumes sequentially. Commodity pricing is much higher than the third quarter to date. Iso to normal butane spreads are up sequentially into the fourth quarter. And you will get a fourth quarter contribution from the recently completed pipes. My question is, if you think Street expectations of just over $20 million higher sequential fourth quarter EBITDA might be light?

headline: ONEOK Partners, L.P., ONEOK Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Craig, from a Street expectation standpoint, what we've told you is that from a financial guidance perspective, we're going to hit our numbers, okay? And so I don't know where that puts you in the fourth quarter relative to the Street. But we feel high
componenttext: So Craig, from a Street expectation standpoint, what we've told you is that from a financial guidance perspective, we're going to hit our numbers, okay? And so I don't know where that puts you in the fourth quarter relative to the Street. But we feel highly confident in our ability to hit this financial guidance. And you're right, there's a lot of noise in the business and the industry. There's a lot of things that move up and down. And you know what? I'm really glad we're in a lot of basins and we've got a lot of leverage to pull. And we've pulled some leverage during the third quarter and we continue to pull leverage each and every quarter. So we've got a lot of optionality, a lot of flexibility, a lot of opportunity. We do have some upside in the fourth quarter. Some of these volumes in the G&P business materializes. These big pads come online. We could see -- it's not gotten cold yet, so you could see some upside in terms of NGL pricing and spreads and what have you. But you also -- you've got headwinds too and you've got heavy inventories in the industry that could weigh on it and some uncertainty in the export markets that could affect the industry near term. All in all, for us, it equates to a high degree of confidence in our ability to hit our numbers in terms of our guidance. Does that help you?

componenttext: Okay, great. And lastly, with M&A, is there any particular side to the business that you would emphasize or a geography like the Permian where you already, obviously, made a move or maybe the Niobrara? Any kind of color on where your wish list would be?

componenttextpreview: Craig, I think from an NGL's perspective, as we look at it, we want to have something that is complementary to the assets that we already have, something that bolts on. I mean, obviously, from a resource play, the Permian's a very good play with West Texa
componenttext: Craig, I think from an NGL's perspective, as we look at it, we want to have something that is complementary to the assets that we already have, something that bolts on. I mean, obviously, from a resource play, the Permian's a very good play with West Texas pipeline. But in other areas, anything we can put into our system to be able to continue that integrated chain is what we're going to be looking at.
